text:
SPEAKER: I want to
introduce Kathy Davies. She is the managing director of
the Stanford Life Design Lab,
and the Life Design Studio lead.

So in addition to
her roles there, she has 15 years of experience
developing electromechanical

and software products, and
proudly holds five patents. She consults with
Silicon Valley companies, teaches design thinking,
as we'll find out today,

conducts ethnographic research
and develops product strategies and concepts. If that were enough, she's
already a Renaissance woman.

She also is the co-creator of
Designing your Life for Women, and a passionate
advocate for design

thinking as a methodology
to empower social change. And so there's a lot
there, Kathy, so welcome.

I'm really excited
for hosting you. KATHY DAVIES: Thanks
for having me. I should probably also
add I'm the mother of two teenage daughters.

So maybe that's even harder
than all of those other things. SPEAKER: Yes, that might be
the hardest thing on the bio,

especially in these
last two years. KATHY DAVIES: The
hardest of them all. SPEAKER: Yeah, wow. KATHY DAVIES: Thanks
for having me back.

SPEAKER: Yeah, it's
great to have you. And I think because we
have such a big audience, probably the place
to start would

just providing some
context on design thinking. So I know it's at the
core of your approach

to a lot of the things you
do, in particular, designing your career and designing
the professional. So could you give us
the 30,000 foot view

of what design thinking is. KATHY DAVIES: Yeah, absolutely. Design thinking at its core
is a human centered process

for problem solving. So it's really about placing
people first, and thinking about how we can solve
problems for them.

And there's a set of five
steps that people think of when they think of design thinking.

The first one is empathize. Who are the people
you're trying to serve? In the case of designing
your own life and career,

that might be yourself. Then there's define, what do
you think is worth working on? Where do you want to focus
your time and energy?

I think a lot of
times when people think of design
thinking, they think of the third step,
ideate, which is all about generating
lots and lots of ideas,

getting really divergent,
getting ideas that you wouldn't normally have. And I want to say that
ideation is awesome,

but that defined step really
determines the kind of ideas that are available to you. So the defined
step is a key bit,

and I think it's
often overlooked. So empathize, define, ideate. Once you have a bunch
of ideas, then you've

got to try them
out in the world, and we call that prototyping. How do you test
them in a small way

to figure out if they are there. You should invest more
time, energy, and resources.

And that testing step,
that fifth step is about taking what you've
built back to the people that you're hoping to
serve and figuring out,

is this something that is
onto the problem they were really curious about solving? Does this meet their needs?

And so you might test
something with yourself, hey, how is this working for me? What do I notice? And all of these steps are
really kind of a bumpy road.

You can iterate and change
step from one to the other. It's not linear at all. It's really a cycle of iteration
of building your way forward,

if you will. SPEAKER: That's fascinating. And thank you for the clear
sort of five-step breakdown.

So I guess following on that, so
when I think of design thinking and it's in your bio as well.

So I think of it as something
that you're applying to developing a product. So I want to create a
new type of software,

a new electromechanical system. So can you tell us
a little bit more about the Life Design Lab,
which first of all, sounds

like probably the coolest
lab on Stanford's campus? And then how that lab or how
the lab was created and came

to use design
thinking to helping people think about their
life and their career?

KATHY DAVIES: Yeah, absolutely. The life Design Lab was
actually founded in 2007. It was founded by our two
lab founders Bill Burnett

and Dave Evans who went on
to write the book Designing Your Life, and then the book
Designing Your New Work Life.

And these two guys got
together and they were just really looking at what was
going on with students. So as you think about that
design thinking process I just

mentioned, they were using
design to design curriculum. And they were asking
themselves, what's going on with
students at that time?

And what was going on
was the same thing that's going on with students now. And in fact, a lot
of you out there,

probably mid-career
professionals, folks who are
thinking about, what do I want to be when I grow up?

Or what do I want
to grow into as I become the next me in the next
phase of my career or life?

And folks are really
struggling with this question. At that time, students were
really struggling, particularly

in product design, because
product design was a relatively new field and many students
were leaving school

with this question of, well,
how do I tell my story? How do I apply this to work
that matters in the world?

And so these two guys sat down
to create a class using design thinking, because that's
the structure that they were

teaching in product
design classes and would be very
familiar to students to work on personal and
professional development.

What would it look like
to design your life and your career? And the uptick was immediate.

Students were very excited
to have these conversations. They weren't able to
have these conversations in any other space.

And the structured
set of activities really gave them a
process to engage with,

how do they become
really more conscious and competent in designing
their life and career?

So that then started
a tiny pilot class that became larger and larger.

It was originally offered just
to product design students. Then Harry Elam and some other
folks from the vise provost

office came in and said, do
you offer this more broadly? So then it was offered
to all students.

And then the
invitation was, well, what about designing
your time at college? And so we set out to design
a class called Designing Your

Stanford that then help
students land at school and think about how
they wanted to design their education for
the four or five years

that they would be here. So our suite of offerings has
become designing your Stanford, designing your life for
juniors and seniors,

and then designing the
professional, which is for graduate students and
now potentially mid-career professionals.

SPEAKER: Yeah, and
maybe just you mentioned taking the structured
approach to it,

because I know there
was nothing like this when I went to college. It was like you go to the
career resources office

and they can review your
resume or something like that or give you tips on applying. So could you-- I mean, I think to some extent,
the value is self-evident,

but could you build out, why
is it so important to approach designing or thinking
about your career in life

in a structured way? Or what feedback
have you gotten? KATHY DAVIES: Yeah, I think
that's a really good question.

And I think mainly
the benefit of having a structure is that you are
held in some sort of a process.

A lot of us have these sort of
broad philosophical questions, but where to start
is just not clear.

And especially now when
there's so much ambiguity, we've gone through two
years of incredible change.

The pandemic has been really
challenging for many of us. Maybe we've lost jobs.

Maybe our home
situation has shifted. Maybe our financial
situation has shifted. We're feeling lost and confused.

And so having a process where we
can locate ourselves, hey, what might be a logical next step?

How could I start addressing
some of these questions is really helpful. And the thing I like about
design thinking in particular

is it doesn't assume
anything about where you are or what resources you have
or what your situation is.

It just meets you
wherever you are. It invites you to
empathize with yourself,

to define things that matter
to you in this moment. It invites you to
come up with ideas

that are applicable to
your current situation and to try them out, given
whatever resources you have.

And what I like about this
in the face of ambiguity is it's comforting. There's enough structure that
I know what I might do next.

But it's not so confining
that I feel like, oh man, I must be doing it wrong.

So it invites all of
us into the process. SPEAKER: So when
the world around you

is so chaotic and
unstructured, it's useful to have a way
of approaching it that is structured,
and that in itself kind of gives you a
way of organizing it.

So I want to go a
little bit off script as it relates to this next
question we have planned. But we're getting a lot
of these questions, well,

so what are some
specific examples? So you laid out the five steps. I'm going to repeat them. Empathize, define, ideate,
prototype, and then test.

Could we maybe just walk
through what might you do? So we have people
here right now,

can you just give
us an example, what might you be doing on that
first step of empathize?

If you're the audience. KATHY DAVIES: We in our
classes really invite people to do some work to
understand themselves.

And so a core piece
of that is assessing where you're at right now. And so we ask people
to do some writing.

As designers, what are
they looking for in work? And by that, I don't
mean a job description.

I mean what's your
philosophy of work. Why work at all?

What's the purpose of work? What's the purpose of work
for you as an individual, for you as playing a
role in your community?

What does money
have to do with it? What does meaning
have to do with it? What is personal growth
have to do with it? So we invite folks
to actually spend

some time reflecting and
writing down their thoughts. And typically, that's about
a half page to a page. We keep it pretty concise.

Then we also ask folks
to think about what's their view of life? What's their world
view, so to speak?

And asking really big questions. Why are we on this planet? What are we doing here? What is the role
of a higher power

in your life and experience? What is the role of
your personal narrative in your experience?

What are the key guiding
principles that you might think are important as
you approach life? And then we look
at those two things

together to create a compass. Are they coherent
with one another? Where do they clash?

Where do they
energize each other? And just that noticing
in that empathize hexagon gives us a foundation
to build from.

And it also gives
us a sense of, hey, if these two things are together
going to potentially point us

in some direction,
how can we use it then in our decision making? How can we evaluate
opportunities

to notice does this fit with
who we are, what we believe,

and what we think we want to do? And so it's a very helpful
compass or strategy,

I think, to start with and to
start understanding ourselves. We also spend some time thinking
about our own identities,

and the narratives that
we've grown up with. What are the stories that
we've heard from our families? What are the stories
we're hearing

in just the world around us? And some of those stories
are really serving us and some of those stories
aren't serving us.

And so we invite that
introspection, if you will, in that first step. So just notice, hey,
what are we working with?

And then from
there, we can define based on what's going on
with us in this moment where we are right now, what
are we willing to work on?

We actually talk
about in life design how there's a step before
any of these others can start called except,
because sometimes we're

ready to work on something and
sometimes we're really not. So are we ready to work on these
things that we're noticing?

And then if we
are, how do we then start defining and scoping
things to take action around.

SPEAKER: And so
defining would be kind of you're distilling
all that you've learned from the empathize
step and you're figuring out

what you're defining,
its defining next steps or defining--

KATHY DAVIES: Exactly. Exactly. So you might note we do a thing
called a balanced assessment.

We look at hey, what's
the role of work? What's the role of
relationships in our lives? What's the role of
play in our lives?

How about our health? And we take stock
of those things. We often think about
work-life balance, but that's not a very
helpful framing, actually.

Giving ourselves more
levers to pull, more aspects to work with, and
gives us a chance

to really focus in on
areas where we might want to define something to change. And so the invitation
is after you notice,
hey, how's it going in work? How satisfied are you? How's it going and love? How satisfied are you?

How's it going with play? How satisfied are you? How's it going with health? How satisfied are you? You might notice, oh,
well, one of these

needs a little attention. And so then the
invitation is OK, well, let's define how might I improve
my health in some small way.

And then we talk about
incremental changes. How can we make
one small change? After we have lots of ideas,
we might pick one of them

to try out. And that trying out
in some tiny way, this is not talking
about boiling the ocean,

this is talking about
trying something maybe for a day or a week to notice,
does it make a difference?

And so that defining
is that first pointer. Hey, what do I want to focus on? Where do I want to
generate some ideas?

And where am I
eventually take on? SPEAKER: That's great. And I want to walk through
some more of these steps,

because this is I
think really helpful. We're getting a lot
of audience questions. But I want to
pause for a second, because we're getting kind
of two related questions

that I think are really
valuable to talk about. So one is, hey, a
mid career, is it

too late to start doing this? Or I just graduated
from high school, is it too late for me
to start doing this?

And so could you talk a little
bit about my understanding is this applies at
any time, and it's not

a thing that you stop doing, a
type of thing you just do once. Can you talk a little
bit about that? And maybe if you have some
experience with people

at different stages, whether
it be high school, college students, or professionals,
talk a little bit about that

and how that's different
for them or the same? KATHY DAVIES:
Yeah, I'm happy to. So I teach students of all
ages from late high school

all the way through, well gosh,
almost to the end of life, really. I've taught folks who are 17,
I've taught folks who are 85.

So everybody is in the same
process, as I mentioned, of hey, what matters to me
and how can I live a life

where I will thrive? So that's a universal
question, I think. And as we go through
different phases of life,

different things or different
constraints might come up. But at the end of
the day, we're all asking these same
kinds of questions.

And this process
is age-agnostic. At any given time, we
can stop take stock,

decide where we want to place
our energy or place our focus, come up with lots of ideas,
decide to try something,

and then test it. If you want to boil
it all down, it really boils down to get
curious, talk to people,

try things, tell your story. We're in this
process of iteration and building our way forward,
because life keeps changing.

So if you're somebody
who's in high school, you might not have
complete agencies. To be perfectly frank, you
might still live at home,

you might have parents,
you might have teachers, you might have constraints
around what you can and cannot

do, because you are not yet
the captain of your own ship. You might not be providing
all of the resources towards what you're doing.

And those people who are
providing the resources may have strong opinions about
what you can and cannot do.

And so really the
invitation is to consider where you do have agencies. So when I work with
young students,

I'm talking a lot
with them about, hey, what are the constraints
that you're working under? And how do we work
inside those constraints

to generate ideas that work,
given the things that you value, the relationships that
you value, and the things

that you're trying
to work within. As we get older, we might
have a little bit more agency. But at the same time, we might
have more responsibility.

Now we've got kids and mortgages
and all these other things. And so the invitation
here is, again,

to define what it is that
matters to you, to consider, hey, what are the constraints
that I can throw off,

because I've just decided
those are fears or those are other things that
are holding me back where I'm holding myself back.

Where are these real
systemic constraints? And then how do I ideate
within those constraints to create prototypes that I can
try to move the ball forward?

So it really is a
universal process. It doesn't matter actually
to me how old you are.

What matters is, are you
willing to get curious? Is this the right time? Are you ready to try something?

And trying something
can be free. It can be something
as small as just talking to someone
about a future life

that you might want to live. Somebody out there is
probably doing the thing that you want to do. Can you have a conversation with
them and learn more about it?

That doesn't cost you anything. But it might be hard to
do, meaning psychologically

difficult to make that
first ask or to reach out. And you may or may
not have the network. So it may take a few steps
to get to that person,

and sometimes that takes
courage and it takes time. So maybe time is
the biggest resource that I see being a
constraint for many of us.

But yeah, universally
applicable, I think. SPEAKER: So yeah, so
any time in your life.

And as you're saying,
it's not just, I mean, we're focused
kind of on career today because that's of particular
interest to lots of people.

It's a very important
part of all our lives. But it can apply
to lots of things

that you're thinking about. How to do better at school. I mean, you said you offer
a version of this course for Stanford graduates as
there are undergrads as they're

planning their trajectory. Yeah. KATHY DAVIES: That's right. SPEAKER: So I'm going to repeat
the steps again because people,

they said I want to
hear those folks again. And then maybe talk a little
bit about the next step,

prototyping. So the first step
is, again empathize. So empathize with
yourself in this case.

What is it you really want? So you're kind of
figuring out what your values are, what you want
out of work, what you want out

of life. And then there's
defining, is taking that to define what are
going to be next steps, and then you generate
some ideas for how you

might take those next steps. And then prototyping, is
that taking that next step?

KATHY DAVIES: That's right. So as we define, we're often
asking ourselves a question, how might I increase the
balance and energy in my life?

How might I try out
some aspect of let's say I want to be a book author,
of being a book author.

And then we might generate
lots and lots of ideas. And the idea of ideation
is about divergence. So one of the things I really
like about this process

is, it invites us
to diverge first. Often, we're really,
really in this space of trying to convert, trying
to get the right answer.

We're trained by
our education system to converge, converge, converge. But in reality
before we converge,

it's nice to really
get all the ideas on the table, even the weird
ideas and the wild ideas. And so I want to talk a
little bit more about ideation

before we get to the
prototyping step, because ideation is
one of those things that we often think
we're good at,

but it takes a lot of
practice to get good. And it really is an invitation
to the wild and weird

and wacky that will
often get us into a space that we hadn't already been in.

If we're stuck and we're in
the same spaces over and over, we're having the
same kinds of ideas, those ideas aren't helping us.

And so we need wild
and wacky ideas. And so in our
classes, we talk a lot about this process of
getting good at ideation.

How do we break out of what we
call schemas, particular trains of thought that are very
common and well-trod, in order

to get into new spaces that
might help us get unstuck. And so we've got lots
of tools to do that. People might have
heard of brainstorming,

we do some verbal
brainstorming in our classes. But we also do things
like idea boarding or mind

mapping or using a technique
called forced morphology to really push our
brains into new spaces

and to think about other ways
to attack the kinds of problems that we're stuck on, so that we
could potentially get unstuck.

So once we've generated
all of those ideas, then we pick some to take
action on, just like you said,

[INAUDIBLE],, the
idea of prototyping is what are we going to try? And prototyping is not
making a huge leap.

Prototyping is,
at its very core, about reducing risk, because
it's scary to change theory

to try new things. So prototyping is
about reducing risk, because we're going to
do something really, really small to see is
there or they're there?

And so we want to do
something that is cheap. We want to do something that
is accessible to us, it's easy.

We don't have a lot of
mental blocks against it. And we wanted
something that's fast, because we want to
get this data quickly,

we don't want to mess around. So we want something that we can
do in a relatively short order. So cheap quick and easy.

That's something to
think about when you're thinking about prototyping. And what we're really talking
about is if we do something,

we learn something. And if we do something,
we engage others often in our process.

So all of a sudden,
we've learned some things about the area
we're curious about, we've potentially
met some people who are interested
in that stuff too.

So now we've got some
collaborators and folks on our team. And we've learned
something about ourselves. Hey, how did that feel
when I did that thing?

And so prototyping is
kind of magic, I think. It's a bias to action
trying things and learning

things on the fly, not
by thinking about them, but doing them. And I think you learn more
that way for many of us

than in any other way. SPEAKER: That's great. And I know something that
comes up something here,

and I think it's out
of-- it might actually be out of Stanford. I can't remember
where the research is, but it was something
like to create

10 products that succeed, you
need 600 ideas or something. We totally
underestimate the number

of ideas you need to
generate to actually create something that's successful. So who knows if that
study is replicated.

I don't know where it's from. But I know it gets
thrown around a lot here. And it's an interesting meme
or way of thinking about it,

that as you said, iteration
is very important. KATHY DAVIES: It is, and it's
also very difficult for people.

And prototyping is
really scary, because we don't want to admit we
don't know the answer. We're afraid we're
going to fail,

we're afraid we're going
to have to throw away work. All of those things
for many of us, especially high achievers
like many of you on this call,

are kicking ass and taking
names to put it just in the vernacular.

You are doing great
work out there, and you are used to
being a high performer. And if you are used to
being a high performer,

the idea of trying something
new that might not work can be terrifying. And so I really just
want to point out,
we are going to fail sometimes. We don't know the answer. The future is unknown.

And we are going to
have to recognize that all of our successes
are the summation

of many, many small tries of
things where we have learned that we're building on.

it is a little scary, but
if there was a better way to do it, I would tell you
it's pretty much necessary.

SPEAKER: And we're getting-- so if it's OK,
let's stay on this-- you're talking about
change is scary,

and especially I want to try a
new job, but do I quit my job? Can I afford to quit
my job, and we're

getting questions around that. What if I want to
explore a new career, but I can't just leave my
current career or yeah,

we've also gotten a couple
of questions of I've invested really a lot of time
into this particular career

and it's an important part
of my conception of myself, but I'm not loving it anymore.

And so maybe that actually comes
back to that empathized step, but could you give
us some examples-- I mean, you've given some.

So it might be talking to
someone in that career, but could you give
some other examples of what a prototype might
be or some of the prototypes

you've seen that
aren't that scary or that are within our reach? KATHY DAVIES: Yeah, absolutely.

The prototype conversation
is easy and very accessible. It's magical, as I mentioned,
because you learn something

about the field that
you're curious about. You also learn something
about yourself, does that person's story
resonate with my story,

and it doesn't involve you
selling yourself or putting out a huge resume or anything. In fact, if you're
trying to have

one of these
conversations, I recommend you don't send your resume,
because it's not about you. You aren't in that
moment job interviewing.

You're doing is really trying
to get someone else's story and trying to understand,
how does that resonate and what are the problems
that they are working on

in this space? Are they problems I thought
they were working on? Are those the problems
that are interesting to me, and as you start having more
and more of these conversations

inside of a given
domain, what happens is you start
understanding the domain, you start having the
language of the domain.

You start sounding
like a domain insider, and suddenly, you are actually
a much more viable job candidate

when and if you decide
to job interview. So prototype
conversations, huge. I want to just hammer
that home as being--

sometimes people call
them info interviews. These are a power tool, and
they work amazingly well.

If you are thinking about
prototype experiences, though, there are
lots of things you can do without quitting your job.

Let's say for example you're
curious about being a book author. Well, write a chapter.

Write a paragraph. Do some small piece of that. Go sit in a coffee shop
and write for a while.

Where do you like to write if
you were curious about writing? Try out a bunch of
different locations. If you're thinking about going
to work at a new company,

go sit in their
lobby for half a day. Just do your regular work from
their lobby on your laptop.

Do you like the
vibe of the place? Are the people walking
in and out looking happy? Do they talk to each
other in the way

that you hope you will
talk with your colleagues? Do they seem like they're
hurried, stress, does it seem like they're relaxed?

What is the feeling of
being in that building. You can learn a lot from
something like that, and again, it costs you nothing.

You could try working or
shadowing someone for a day. You could take on an
assignment while someone else is on maternity or
paternity leave.

You could take on an
assignment that is small enough that you can get a taste
of some new aspect of a job

inside your current job. Maybe I'm interested in moving
from engineering to marketing, say.

Could I decide to
write a marketing blurb about the product
that I'm building

and just bounce it off someone
in marketing in my company. Not because my blurb
necessarily would be used, not because I'm going
to take over comms altogether,

but by just practicing
that and getting a little feedback from a
colleague, I can learn, do I like doing that?

Am I any good at it
to start with skills might I need to build in
order to move into that space.

And so I think we often
think about huge moves. I'm going to go intern
for three months. I'm going to quit my job and
become a bartender in Belize.

Well, before I quit my job and
become a bartender in Belize, why don't I just make a few
drinks for friends at a party

and see, do I like doing
that, taking orders? Can I remember all
the ingredients? There's some little
thing that you

can do to just taste a
tiny bit of the future that you want to hold, and so
I think prototype conversations

and prototype experiences both
are accessible to all of us, regardless of resources
and regardless of where we are in our careers.

SPEAKER: And just--
that's fantastic. And it's interesting,
and I want to come back, so again, I'm going
to say them again.

So the empathize, define,
ideate, prototype, test. And so it just one question.

Say you prototype something. Say you go, I want to
be a bartender in Belize or something and then you
go and you do some drinks.

You're like, you know what? I make a terrible mojito. I can't remember drink orders. This isn't for me. Do you then-- can you
go back to any stage?

Do you go back and go, I
also just didn't like it as much as I thought I
would like it, and so do you then go back to the
empathize stage or do you go--

I know it's not
a linear process. You said that at the beginning. Can you just talk
about how you might-- OK, I've prototyped something.

KATHY DAVIES: What next? SPEAKER: It's not real. What next, yeah. KATHY DAVIES: Yeah,

KATHY DAVIES: Yeah, absolutely. So after we've done a
bunch of small prototypes one of the things we
might invite people to do

is take a look at potential
futures for themselves. For our students who
are just graduating,

they've never had jobs
from in some cases, or if they have
had, there typically

have been part time jobs. We do have some students
who've taken gap years and they've gone off
and had full time jobs for some period of time,
but many of our students

haven't even worked yet. When I think about folks
who are out there who are mid-career professionals
or folks in later parts

of their career, they might also
be asking the same question, what next? What do I want to do next, and
our temptation is to think,

I've got to figure
out the best option. I've got to figure it
out and then execute. But the hard part about that
is, by forcing ourselves

into a singular plan,
all of a sudden, there's a lot of pressure. So what odyssey's
are, odysseys are

three very different visions
of your next five years. We invite people to
create a timeline

for each of those versions
of their future self. We invite them to look at
major personal and professional

milestones. One in each year at least. If you've been thinking a lot
about that work love health

play assessment, we might
even invite, think about what are you going to be
doing for work in each of those years, what are you
going to be doing to build

relationships in each of those
years, and by relationships, by the way, I don't mean
romantic relationships solely.

I mean relationships
of all kinds who are the people that you care
about and that care about you. Maybe even pets or other aspects
of relationship in your life.

What are you going
to be doing for play in each of those five years? How are you taking care of your
health in each of those five

years, and each of these lives
should be radically different from the other, not
because necessarily already

have three random
ideas for your future but by forcing yourself
to think about, hey,

what if the life I
was leading right now played out in the
best possible way? What if I couldn't do what
I'm doing right now, not

because I'm not awesome, but
because this industry goes away? We've been seeing in a lot
of places in the world shifts

in what's available
in terms of work just because things
are changing. Computer science is
suddenly a thing.

That wasn't even
existent 30 years ago. There are all these
different opportunities that are changing and growing
as the conditions around us

change, so the
idea that we aren't doing what we're currently
doing but we still have all of our wonderful
skills that we have picked up

over time that we could
apply to a new thing is an interesting one to ponder.

So how would I apply my
skills to something else if I wasn't doing what
I'm doing currently, and then we invite people to
think about the wild card life.

This is the bartender in
Belize thing for some of us. What would I do if I
had no constraints? If I had all the money I needed,
if no one would laugh at me,

if societal constraints
were released, if gender-based
constraints were released.

If I could throw off as
many constraints as I can and think super wildly,
what would I do?

So those three framings are
sometimes helpful as we think about these five year futures.

And then we play them
out, so on paper, and then we look at them, we notice,
how do I feel about them?

Because in some ways, these are
both ideas and tiny prototypes. We get the ideas
out there, we think

of these really
divergent futures, and then we take a
moment to take stock. How does that strike me?
What would I call this life? We have people title the life. Five words or less. Just a quick title.

Kathy bartends in Belize and
Kathy takes over higher ed.

Kathy heads back to industry. Those might be my three titles,
and then I look at, well,

do I like it? Do I have the
resources to do it? Am I confident I
could pull it off,

and then because we've done
a bunch of empathy work we noticed is this
coherent with what

I said I wanted it to work,
what I said my life view was, what I notice in terms of
my balanced assessment what

I notice in terms of flow. All of the other
tools and activities that we've done in our class.

So we get a sense of,
does this fit who I am and who I want to become?

And that invitation
is doubled down upon by sharing them
verbally with our peers.

So then we get into a
group of three people, and each person shares out

of their future. And what's fascinating is you
can see it in people's body

and in their voice
where they're excited. You have the person who is like,
well, I guess what I would do.

As soon as you hear

you know this isn't
maybe their story. This is the story that somebody

all of a sudden, you

language, I'm stoked about the idea of setting

I want to do that. And so our peers can

Where it sounds like a story
that our heart is in, and then that's new data.

And once we've got

like, OK, well, if I wanted one of these things,

Little tiny prototype

As meaningful as I

I can make a fourth, a fifth. I can combine them together,

Where are they threads that
I want to take action around. Not huge action. Not quit my job and

just trying it out
action, because I'm going to sneak up on
